title: Hundreds of migrants brave freezing conditions to queue for food in scenes which echo WW2 camps
text:
Hundreds of migrants brave freezing conditions to queue for food in scenes which echo WW2 camps Temperatures in Belgrade, Serbia, where around 1,500 migrants are sheltering in warehouses, have plunged to -20C Share By Natalie Evans Marton Dunai 02:19, 10 JAN 2017 Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Migrants battle freezing temperatures in Serbia and Hungary Share this video Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Wrapped in blankets with little more than woolly hats and umbrellas to shield them from heavy snowfall , hundreds of migrants queue for free food in Serbia. 
The harrowing scenes are reminiscent of images from World War Two, showing German prisoners of war braced against the bitter cold in in Stalingrad. Read More Hundreds of migrants queue for food in the snow in Belgrade (Photo: REUTERS) The scenes are reminiscent of WW2 prisoner of war camps (Photo: Corbis Historical) 
Hundreds of men, mainly Afghans, slept on concrete floors, burning plastic rubbish to keep warm which gave off choking black smoke. 
They are among 7,000 stranded in Serbia. 
Refugee camps are packed and only women and children are likely to be let in, leaving the men to seek shelter where they can - in abandoned warehouses in central Belgrade or the fields just south of the border. Around 1,500 migrants have been sheltering in warehouses in Belgrade (Photo: REUTERS) 
Amin Jahn, from Pakistan, said: "Actually the cold is too much and last night we didn't sleep, we (were) all sitting around the fire and it was too cold, I think it was minus 16, 15 (Celsius) last night. 
"Try to arrange something for us and try to open the border. It's our request." 
Authorities say most of Serbia's estimated 7,000 migrants are from Afghanistan, Iraq or Syria. 
Dozens of Asian, Afghan and Pakistani migrants, some with children, are camping out in makeshift tents on Serbia's northern border, waiting for their turn to try to enter Hungary. Read More Big freeze leaves more than 20 dead across Europe - and it's heading for Britain Temperatures in the Serbian capital plunged to -20C (Photo: REUTERS) 
Hungary registered 30,000 asylum applications last year, according to the government, of which fewer than half were accepted. 
In addition, nearly 20,000 gave up on the official process and tried to enter illegally. 
In some ways, those in the tents are the lucky ones - those who are near the front of an unofficial refugee-administered queue to submit an asylum application at one of only two recognised crossing points - Horgos and Tompa. 
But in the current, brutal cold snap, they pay a high price. 
Their rickety teepees, lined with blankets, are heated only with campfire embers brought inside at nightfall. 
Many of the children who crawl outside at first light are wearing only thin sweaters and slippers. The migrants are among 7,000 stranded in Serbia (Photo: REUTERS) 
All this to be one of the lucky few allowed to submit a Hungarian asylum application in tiny container offices set up for the purpose at Horgos and Tompa, in the hope of then being admitted to a Transit Zone, and eventually becoming one of the 10 refugees a day allowed to enter Hungary from each post. 
Milana Radosavljevic, a physician from Doctors Without Borders, told Reuters: "People are suffering too much and they have a lot of respiratory infections." 
Hungary has made clear that it does not welcome migrants; Prime Minister Viktor Orban has fortified the border, an external frontier of the European Union, with a razor wire fence, and thousands of police and soldiers patrol the area with heat-sensitive cameras and helicopters. Like us on Facebook
